    • Method Detail

      • isAbbreviation

        public static boolean isAbbreviation(TextDiff diff,
                                     java.lang.String strA,
                                     java.lang.String strB,
                                     int requiredSharedChars)
        Return true if it is reasonable to assume strA and strB are equivalent because of the use of abbreviations. This assumes the Strings are expressed in English.

        For example if this compares "agri department" with "agriculture dept" it will return true. Note neither String is strictly an abbreviation of the other, but if you split them into individual words: it can be said that each word is an abbreviation of the other.

        This strips out small helper words (like "a", "the", "of") in this comparison, and looks for common prefixes and suffixes (while "important" is a subset of "unimportant", the former shouldn't be considered an abbreviation of the latter).

        This method is case insensitive, may also strip out some punctuation characters.

        Parameters:
        diff - an optional TextDiff. Each TextDiff object caches results, so if you have frequent (and finite) Strings to compare, you may want to reuse the same TextDiff object. Otherwise one is created and destroyed.
        strA - the first string to compare.
        strB - the second string to compare.
        Returns:

      • getMeaningfulWords

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getMeaningfulWords(java.lang.CharSequence str)
        This collapses white space, identifies alphanumeric chars, and removes small words like "a", "of" or "the" (words you wouldn't capitalize in a book title).
        Parameters:
        str - the characters to extract words from.
        Returns:
        the list of words extracted from the argument.
